bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Frederick F. Russell, August 15, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302047]

div1.p: Hanson relates his belief that yellow fever is moving from the Colombian interior towards the coast by river and states that the clean up campaign will need to be expanded and will require considerable funds if it is to be effective.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Frederick F. Russell, August 15, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302047]
div1.opener:
COPY
(2) Colombia (2) Carter
INTERNATIONAL HEALTH BOARD
61 Broadway, New York
Bogota, Columbia
August 15, 1923
Col F. F. Russell
General Director
International Health Board
New York City
My dear Col. Russell:
div1.p:
So far we are “making haste slowly” but I am hoping that we
shall be able to get our affairs arranged so that we can leave here on
Saturday afternoon. We want to spend a day in Girardot as we go down
for the purpose of finding out what their Stegomyia index is and if
there are any suspicious cases of sickness. From there we go to Barranca
Bermeja where we will spend about two days, this for the purpose of find-
ing out what is possible about the “pernicious fevers” reported, following
which we will go to Bucaramanga.

As things appear now I doubt that the Bucaramanga region is of
the greatest importance for the present. If the rumors which I have heard
have any foundation, i.e. such as the report of cases dying with black vomit
in Puerto Santos which is on the Le Brija River and in fairly easy and
direct communication with Banco (population 5167) and other points on the
Magdelena river, the problem then will be to save the large coast towns;
Cartagena, Barranquilla and others. Calamar which is six hours from Bar-
ranquilla by steamer going down the river, is a town of 6000 and over ac-
cording to statistical reports. Up the river we have Honda with over 8000
and Girardot with more than 10,000, some say 18,000.

If we find the fever in such outside points as Puerto
Santos, Puerto Wilches and the Village of Barranca it is quite certain that
the infection is actually being relayed towards the coast in many ways; such
Col. F. F. Russell
-2-
August 15, 1923
as travel from village to village in the canoes, small launches and passen-
gers on the large steamers who go only from port to port, besides the peones
who travel afoot and the different pack trains. It is useless to talk
about a quarantine in a country of this kind, as it would be quite mislead-
ing to depend upon it to control the spread of the fever. The serious side
of this is that it appears that we shall be obliged to very considerably
extend the sphere of our operations, and to make quite a decided change in
what might be called the strategy of the campaign. To me it seems that if
we wish to avoid the disaster of having the fever reach the coast a campaign
should be commenced with as little delay as possible in the coast towns.
Such a program will be expensive, principally due to the very high cost of
all articles of equipment and the comparatively high wages which one has to
pay the employees. It seems that the lowest paid inspector gets $60.00
pesos per month. The native supervisors in Bucaramanga are getting from
$80.00 to $100.00 per month. This about twice what I paid in Peru. Trans-
portation is equally expensive and as slow as it is expensive. The problem
is much more complex than I gathered from my conversations with Dr. White,
and from the few experiences which I have had so far there is not such
thing as being comfortable anywhere except here in Bogota, and as soon as
we get our resolutions passed we will have very little occasion for being
here, except once in a long while to attend some business matter.

The places which have had these rumored cases are all outside
of the zone of activities of the Bucaramanga campaign, but are either on
or sufficiently close to the river towns to start a series of relays. For
the present Cucuta is a little importance as a factor of the spread of the
fever in Colombia is concerned, and if it has been recently infected the
mischief has already been done on the Venezuelan side. This I will investi-
gate as soon as I have the Magdelena valley region organized.

Rents are high, and a house which could serve both as the main
office and living quarters for the men who are away from home would cost
from $150.00 to $200.00 per month.

The question of a secretary, which is indispensable, who knows
something about both languages and short hand will cost from $200.00 to
$250.00 per month and travel expense when away from home. These prices
have rather stunned me, but it is no use to attempt work of this kind
unless one does it right. If one is to succeed one must have the necessary
help of the right kind, and poorly paid help very rarely is worth having.

When I consider the hardships of travel, and there will be a
lot of it, $400.00 and all expenses is the minimum which can be offered
to any worth while Inspector who we might need to bring in to help out in
the organization of the work. Any good man who is brought in for less is
going to feel that he has been imposed upon and will be a dissatisfied
worker.

I shall be unable to report anything more definite until after
the investigation in Bucaramanga.

“As to the probability of bringing my family down to this coun-
try, I must say that it seems quite out of the question. The trip up the
river would be far too hard for Mrs. Hanson and the little children. The
food is such that the children would certainly get sick, and there is not
a comfortable cabin on any of the boats. The only thing which I have considered
would be the probability of getting a house for them if possible at some high
cool point on Ancon Hill. Col Fisher and the Governor agreed to help me in
this matter in case I decided to do so. I would be able to see them occasion-
ally there as one could go from Puerto Colombia to Cristobal in two days.
The idea of being here for two years with the family in the states is far
from ideal. I have not heard a word from them since leaving Sioux City,
Iowa.”
